chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should set a universal minimum standard of coverage so everyone can access primary, preventive, mental-health, and urgent care, and no one is bankrupted by serious illness. It should finance this floor transparently, negotiate and police fair prices, and measure outcomes to curb waste while keeping enrollment and billing simple. Beyond the baseline, people and employers should be free to choose supplemental private plans and diverse delivery models, with partnerships that strengthen local clinics and rural access.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee universal access to an affordable baseline of essential care—primary, preventive, mental-health, and emergency services—and protect everyone from catastrophic medical costs. That guarantee should come with strong cost and quality safeguards, including transparent pricing, streamlined administration/enrollment, and outcome-based accountability to ensure fiscal responsibility. Within this public floor, preserve patient choice by partnering with community providers and allowing private supplemental coverage and innovation so the system remains responsive and sustainable.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should guarantee that every American can afford timely access to essential care—primary, preventive, mental health, and emergency services—and is protected from catastrophic medical bills, without forcing people to give up their doctor. To earn broad trust, the program should be fiscally responsible with transparent prices, tough anti-fraud enforcement, and payment tied to outcomes that reward quality over volume. Private and employer coverage should remain available for supplemental benefits, while partnering with local hospitals, community clinics, and faith-based providers to expand access and reduce bureaucracy.
